document.title: Subgaussian random variables, Hoeffding’s inequality, and Cramér’s large deviation theorem

Math.text: (integral _ R)@(e ^ (t * x) * differential-d@(gamma _ (list@(0, b ^ 2))) * x) = (integral _ R)@(e ^ (b * t * y) * (1 / square-root@(2 * pi)) * e ^ (- y ^ 2 / 2) * differential-d@(y)) = (integral _ R)@(e ^ ((b ^ 2 * t ^ 2) / 2) * (1 / square-root@(2 * pi)) * e ^ (- (y - b * t) ^ 2 / 2) * differential-d@(y)) = e ^ ((b ^ 2 * t ^ 2) / 2)

Stromberg attributes the following theorem to Saeki; further, it is proved in Stromberg that if for some
t
the inequality in the theorem is an equality then the random variable has the Rademacher distribution. 2 footnote 2 2 footnote 2 Karl R. Stromberg, Probability for Analysts, p. 293, Proposition 9.9; Omar Rivasplata, Subgaussian random variables: An expository note, http://www.math.ualberta.ca/~orivasplata/publications/subgaussians.pdf

If
X

Math.text: formulae@(E * e ^ (t * X) less= hyperbolic-cosine@(t), t element-of R)

para.p:
Define
: f
→ R R
by

Math.text: f * t = e ^ t * (hyperbolic-cosine@(t) - E * e ^ (t * X)) = (e ^ (2 * t) / 2 + 1 / 2) - e ^ t * E * e ^ (t * X)

para.p: Then

Math.text: f ^ prime * t = e ^ (2 * t) - e ^ t * E * e ^ (t * X) - e ^ t * E * X * e ^ (t * X)

We first prove Hoeffding’s lemma. 3 footnote 3 3 footnote 3 Stéphane Boucheron, Gábor Lugosi, and Pascal Massart, Concentration Inequalities: A Nonasymptotic Theory of Independence, p. 27, Lemma 2.2.

para.p: and so

Var * X _ lambda
absent = E * (X _ lambda) ^ 2 - E * (X _ lambda) ^ 2
absent = (E * X ^ 2 * e ^ (lambda * X)) / e ^ (Lambda * lambda) - (E * (X * e ^ (lambda * X)) ^ 2) / e ^ (2 * Lambda * lambda)
absent = (E * X ^ 2 * e ^ (lambda * X)) / e ^ (Lambda * lambda) - (E * (X * e ^ (lambda * X)) ^ 2) / e ^ (2 * Lambda * lambda)

para.p: hence
Thus, () is equivalent to

para.p: so, to prove the claim it suffices to prove that

Math.text: (limit-infimum _ (n to infinity))@((1 / n) * logarithm@(E * (1 _ [{Tn≥0}] cdot e ^ (- tau * T _ n)))) >= 0

Math.text: Lambda * t = logarithm@((integral _ R)@(e ^ (t * x) * differential-d@(gamma _ (list@(0, 1))) * x))
Lambda * t
absent = logarithm@((integral _ R)@(e ^ (t * x) * differential-d@(gamma _ (list@(0, 1))) * x))
absent = logarithm@((integral _ R)@(e ^ (t * x) * (e ^ (- x ^ 2 / 2) / square-root@(2 * pi)) * differential-d@(x)))
absent = logarithm@((integral _ R)@(e ^ (t * x) * (e ^ (- x ^ 2 / 2) / square-root@(2 * pi)) * differential-d@(x)))
absent = logarithm@((integral _ R)@((e ^ (- (1 / 2) * (x - t) ^ 2) / square-root@(2 * pi)) * e ^ (t ^ 2 / 2) * differential-d@(x)))
absent = logarithm@((integral _ R)@((e ^ (- (1 / 2) * (x - t) ^ 2) / square-root@(2 * pi)) * e ^ (t ^ 2 / 2) * differential-d@(x)))
absent = logarithm@(e ^ t ^ 2 * 2)
absent = logarithm@(e ^ t ^ 2 * 2)
absent = t ^ 2 / 2
absent = t ^ 2 / 2

para.p:
thus
<
⁢ Λ
( t )
∞
for all
t
. Then

Math.text: Lambda ^ * * x = (supremum _ (t element-of R))@(t * x - Lambda * t) = (supremum _ (t element-of R))@(t * x - t ^ 2 / 2) = x ^ 2 / 2

Another example: If
X n
are independent identically distributed random variables with the Rademacher distribution:
Then

Math.text: E * e ^ (t * X _ 1) = (integral _ R)@(e ^ (t * x) * d * ((1 / 2) * delta _ (- 1) + (1 / 2) * delta _ 1) * x) = (1 / 2) * e ^ (- t) + (1 / 2) * e ^ t = hyperbolic-cosine@(t)

para.p:
so the cumulant generating function of
X 1
is

Math.text: Lambda * t = logarithm@(hyperbolic-cosine@(t))

para.p:
and indeed
<
⁢ Λ
( t )
∞
for all
∈ t R
. Then, as
=
⁢
d

(
-
⁢ t x
log

- x

,

Math.text: Lambda ^ * * x = (supremum _ (t element-of R))@(t * x - logarithm@(hyperbolic-cosine@(t))) = (arctanh * x) cdot x - logarithm@(hyperbolic-cosine@(arctanh * x))
arctanh * x = (1 / 2) * logarithm@((1 + x) / (1 - x))

para.p: Then

Math.text: hyperbolic-cosine@(arctanh * x) = (1 / 2) * (e ^ (arctanh * x) + e ^ (- arctanh * x)) = (1 / 2) * square-root@((1 + x) / (1 - x)) + (1 / 2) * square-root@((1 - x) / (1 + x)) = 1 / square-root@(1 - x ^ 2)

para.p: With these identities,

Math.text: Lambda ^ * * t = (x / 2) * logarithm@((1 + x) / (1 - x)) + (1 / 2) * logarithm@(1 - x ^ 2)
Lambda ^ * * t
absent = (x / 2) * logarithm@((1 + x) / (1 - x)) + (1 / 2) * logarithm@(1 - x ^ 2)
absent = ((x / 2) * logarithm@(1 + x) - (x / 2) * logarithm@(1 - x)) + (1 / 2) * logarithm@(1 + x) + (1 / 2) * logarithm@(1 - x)
absent = ((x / 2) * logarithm@(1 + x) - (x / 2) * logarithm@(1 - x)) + (1 / 2) * logarithm@(1 + x) + (1 / 2) * logarithm@(1 - x)
absent = ((1 + x) / 2) * logarithm@(1 + x) + ((1 - x) / 2) * logarithm@(1 - x)
absent = ((1 + x) / 2) * logarithm@(1 + x) + ((1 - x) / 2) * logarithm@(1 - x)

para.p:
Thus for all

Math.text: t * M _ 1 - logarithm@(check@(mu)) * t less= 0

para.p:
For a Borel probability measure
μ
with finite first moment, we define its Cramér transform
:
I μ
→ R

by 7 footnote 7 7 footnote 7 Heinz Bauer, Probability Theory, pp. 89–90, §12.

Math.text: I _ mu * x = (supremum _ (t element-of R))@(t * x - logarithm@(check@(mu)) * t)
